sentences: Minulla on kaksi kissaa ja kolme koiraa.
context: The Finnish word 'to' is the third-person singular form of the verb 'olla' (to be), used to indicate possession or existence. When followed by a noun in the partitive case, it means someone has something - similar to the English structure 'someone has/has got'. The subject is indicated by the personal pronoun ending on the verb: hänellä = he/she has; minulla = I have; meillä = we have.
